436.text:
Students must cover a range of different types

455.text:
This topic explores markets and customer wants
and needs.

459.text:
Issues to explore include: markets are made
up of buyers and sellers. Successful businesses

468.text:
will be part of a market that is different
in size and character, and affected by change.

475.text:
Within markets, customers have needs and wants
needs, like water, are unavoidable but wants

481.text:
are different in the sense that the consumer
will have some choice about them. A successful

488.text:
product or service and therefore business
will most likely benefit from effective market

493.text:
research to enable the business to provide
consumers with the choices that meet their

498.text:
needs and wants. A successful business will
position itself in a market in such a way

504.text:
as to ensure effective sales in what may be
a very competitive environment.

511.text:
Highlights within this topic include an emphasis
on dynamic markets and the use of ICT.

522.text: This topic looks at the market in more detail.

527.text:
It focuses on the interaction between buyers
(consumers) and sellers (producers) and explores

534.text:
the factors that affect demand and supply,
determining price levels and sales. The sensitivity

541.text:
of demand to price changes and changes in
income provide opportunities for demonstrating

547.text:
quantitative skills. New quantitative skills
introduced here are price elasticity of demand

555.text:
and income elasticity of demand. The emphasis
in this topic is on the impact of the market

562.text:
and changes in market conditions on business
and should not be viewed as a topic on economics!

571.text:
This topic explores the marketing mix and
strategy.

579.text:
Students will explore the appropriate nature
of the marketing mix (the 4Ps product, promotion,

586.text:
price and place) for new or existing products
or services. Students will also consider how

593.text:
social trends may affect the marketing mix;
the Boston Matrix, the product life cycle

598.text:
and its related sales extension strategies,
with reference to product and promotional

603.text:
methods; and marketing strategies that relate
to niche, mass, business to business or business

610.text:
to consumer marketing, and the benefits and
limitations of these strategies.

616.text:
Social trends are considered within each element
of the marketing mix to keep content and examples

622.text:
up-to-date and allow relevant/topical case
studies to be used in class. It also means

628.text:
students can be engaged by recent developments
in this area.

635.text: This topic focuses on managing people.

641.text:
In this section the focus is on human resource
issues, with consideration of how employees

649.text:
can be effectively recruited, deployed, developed
and trained, motivated, managed and led. The

658.text:
specific theories/theorists required are listed
in the specification others can be used (and

666.text:
will be rewarded in the assessments) for context.
The specification does not require learning

671.text:
lots of theories but students must understand
the key principles in these areas.

Theme 1.

686.text:
This topic focuses on how people set up and
succeed in operating their own business and

693.text:
the constraints they might face in doing so.
Students will also consider the people skills

699.text:
and personal qualities that entrepreneurs
will most likely need to succeed; what drives

705.text:
people to set up their own business; business
objectives; and the various forms of business

710.text:
ownership and the choices which typically
face owners of a business.

714.text:
The emphasis here is on understanding entrepreneurs
and that they have different motives and objectives.

723.text:
Students will also consider entrepreneurs
developing into leaders.
